conclusion: To determine which blocks object A will collide with and its final landing position, reasoning will be based on gravity, collision, and deflection effects observed in the scene.
Object A is shown falling towards a group of yellow blocks, with the trajectory indicated by the red arrow aimed directly at the top right yellow block.
Gravity will cause A to fall straight down in the absence of air resistance or other forces.
Assuming no external forces except gravity, A should hit the block it is aimed at, i.e., the top right yellow block.

When A collides with the top yellow block, there are two possible outcomes depending on the properties of A and the blocks: inelastic collision may cause both to fall together, or elastic collision may cause A to bounce off.
In the second picture, the orange object A has landed on top of the two yellow blocks, and the yellow blocks appear undisturbed.

Given that A is now on top of the yellow blocks, it confirms that A collided with the top yellow block and likely had an inelastic or partially inelastic collision, allowing it to rest on top of the blocks.

Object A will collide with the top right yellow block and will land on top of the two yellow blocks as seen in the final scene. The collision appears to be inelastic or partially inelastic, resulting in A resting on the blocks without significant displacement of the blocks themselves.
